verses.text: But as for you, speak what is fitting for sound teaching.
verses.comment: Paul exhorts Titus, like Timothy, to uphold doctrine grounded in truth rather than speculation (see 1 Tim. 1:10). This highlights the emphasis on a unified apostolic teaching, guided by tradition handed down from the apostles.

verses.text: Older men are to be temperate, dignified, self-controlled, sound in faith, in love, in perseverance.
verses.comment: The call for mature men to live virtuously echoes lists of overseer qualifications (1 Tim. 3). Perseverance in faith and love are the marks of genuine discipleship and enduring witness.

verses.text: Older women likewise are to be reverent in their behavior, not slanderers or enslaved to much wine; teaching what is good,
verses.comment: After the order for men, Paul addresses women’s role as examples and teachers within the community, showing the intergenerational transfer of faith and virtue. Reverence and restraint are essential qualities for those who instruct others, a model emulated by generations in the visible church.

verses.text: so that they may train the younger women to love their husbands and children,
verses.comment: Here, Paul affirms the family as the basic unit for passing on faith, with older women serving as guides for younger generations—a living tradition within the community. Love for family is foundational for Christian witness.

verses.text: to be self-controlled, pure, busy at home, kind, being subject to their own husbands, so that the word of God may not be slandered.
verses.comment: Submission and purity are not cultural relics, but ways the gospel is made attractive and compelling. The virtue of obedience is held as a sign of a sanctified heart, reflecting Christ’s own submission to the Father.

verses.text: Urge the younger men likewise to be self-controlled.
verses.comment: Self-control is a fruit of the Spirit and foundational for spiritual leadership (cf. Gal. 5:23). Paul’s instructions align all believers under one moral discipline, showing the need for consistent, lived-out doctrine.

verses.text: In all things show yourself to be an example of good works, with integrity in teaching, dignity,
verses.comment: Leaders are called to embody the gospel through visible deeds and faithful doctrine. Living as a model affirms the inseparable bond between faith and works (see James 2:17-18).

verses.text: and sound speech that cannot be condemned, so that those who oppose you may be put to shame, having nothing evil to say about us.
verses.comment: Speaking the truth in love protects the unity and witness of the Church. Even opponents are left without cause for criticism when the community’s life reflects holiness and charity.

verses.text: Urge servants to be submissive to their own masters in everything, to be well-pleasing, not talking back,
verses.comment: Obedience to earthly authorities, even in humble positions, manifests the humility of Christ (see Phil. 2:5-8). Early Christians transform society from within through exemplary conduct.

verses.text: not stealing, but showing all good faith, so that in everything they may adorn the teaching of God our Savior.
verses.comment: A consistent life enhances the beauty of the gospel and displays God in action. Faith is not hidden but displayed in full public view, upholding the unity and holiness of the apostolic community.

verses.text: For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation to all people,
verses.comment: The appearance of grace is the incarnation of Christ (cf. John 1:14), the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy and the universal offer of salvation. The phrase points to the objective reality of grace entering history through the person of Jesus.

verses.text: instructing us to deny ungodliness and worldly desires, and to live self-controlled, upright, and godly lives in this present age,
verses.comment: Grace does not excuse sin but empowers a new way of living (cf. Rom. 6:1-4). Moral transformation is the visible evidence of the invisible work of grace—connecting faith, works, and sanctification.

verses.text: as we wait for the blessed hope—the appearing of the glory of our great God and Savior, Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: High Christology: Paul calls Jesus both 'God and Savior', a direct affirmation of Christ’s divinity (cf. John 20:28). The passage looks forward to His second coming, uniting the hope of the Church through every age (see also Matt. 24:30).

verses.text: He gave Himself for us, to redeem us from all lawlessness and to purify for Himself a people for His own possession, zealous for good works.
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills the promise of redemption, echoing Israel’s deliverance in the Old Covenant (see Ex. 19:5). The formation of a purified, eager people parallels the Church as Christ’s chosen assembly, set apart for good works (cf. Eph. 2:10).

verses.text: Declare these things. Encourage and correct with all authority. Let no one disregard you.
verses.comment: Titus is given not only responsibility but apostolic authority to teach, exhort, and rebuke. This echoes the continued authority of overseers and the importance of adhering to the tradition once for all entrusted to the saints (see Jude 3).
